explanation: For each pointer-related MISRA C analysis we need the declarations and types of all functions, types and global variables that are passed by address or otherwise involve pointers so we can determine whether the called function writes through the pointer (thus requiring a non-const target) or could accept a pointer-to-const. - clock_gettime, struct timespec, clockid_t and the CLOCK_* constants: the prototype (int clock_gettime(clockid_t, struct timespec *)) and timespec type tell us whether &ts is an OUT parameter (written) and therefore must be non-const. - host_get_clock_service, mach_host_self, SYSTEM_CLOCK, clock_get_time, mach_timespec_t, clock_serv_t / mach_port_t (mono_clock_service type), KERN_SUCCESS, mach_port_deallocate, mach_task_self: these Darwin/Mach APIs take pointer/out-parameter types (e.g. clock_serv_t * or mach_timespec_t *) or return ports; we need their prototypes and the type of mono_clock_service to know whether addresses passed are modified (non-const) and whether mach_port_deallocate expects a value or pointer. - GetTickCount64: signature and return type to know tick_start assignment (no pointer) but included to understand alternatives used instead of pointer-passing. - QueryPerformanceFrequency, QueryPerformanceCounter, LARGE_INTEGER: these WinAPI functions write into LARGE_INTEGER* parameters; prototypes are required to show that &freq and &perf_counter are OUT parameters, so the pointers must not be const. - gethrtime: declaration to confirm whether it returns a value (no pointer) and how hrtime_start is set. - timespec_get, TIME_UTC: prototype int timespec_get(struct timespec *, int) to confirm &tsg is written. - gettimeofday, struct timeval: prototype int gettimeofday(struct timeval *, void *) confirms &tv is an OUT parameter. - time, time_t: prototype time_t time(time_t *) confirms time(NULL) use and sys_clock_start type. - enum _MHD_mono_clock_source and the global variables mono_clock_id, mono_clock_start, mono_clock_service, mono_clock_source, tick_start, perf_freq, perf_start, hrtime_start, gettime_start, sys_clock_start: their types are required to check whether any addresses or pointers to these globals are created or passed elsewhere and to ensure correct const qualification of pointers to these globals (and to confirm that the code writes to these globals, which affects pointer const reasoning). In short, to decide if any pointer could or should be const-qualified you must inspect the called APIs' parameter qualifiers and the types of all variables whose addresses are taken; the listed symbols are exactly those declarations and globals needed for that determination.
